newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa union says Sappi strike to spread.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa union says Sappi strike to spread.

text.p: South African paper union PPWAWU said on Thursday the strike at Sappi Ltd's Adamas mill in Port Elizabeth remained unresolved and would spread to other mills in sympathy.

"We are negotiating with our members to write letters to their plant managers according to the Labour Relations Act informing them that they will be in a solidarity strike," Sakhiwo Zako, Paper, Printing, Wood and Allied Workers' Union spokesman said.

He said they were also negotiating with other paper factories in the country and in the United States related to Sappi to refuse to handle their products. He said they were receiving good indications from them.
Some 200 workers are striking to demand a 10 percent annual wage increase. Sappi is offering an increase of six percent now with a further four percent in six months' time.
Negotiations broke down on April 23 and as yet there were no talks betweeen the two parties to resolve the dispute.
Sappi said in a statement production was not affected but the union disputed that.
"They would like to believe that. All the workforce of about 200 workers is not working," a union official at the mill said.
Sappi issued a statement last night declining to comment on the solidarity action by the union.
